newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission delays mad cow, gelatine measures.
newsitem.headline: Commission delays mad cow, gelatine measures.

text.p: The European Commission has postponed until next week a proposal for further measures, including a ban on exports of British gelatine, to combat mad cow disease, Commission officials said on Monday.
Food safety commissioner Emma Bonino, who is trying to speed up implementation of advice given by scientific committees, said last week she hoped the proposal would be adopted this week.
But officials said the proposal, which is being drawn up with Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler, had not yet been vetted by the 20 commissioners' aides.
On April 3, the multidisciplinary scientific committee raised doubts about the safety of British gelatine and the Commission had been expected to restore the ban by May 1.

The gelatine ban was part of a worldwide embargo on British beef exports imposed by the EU in March 1996 after London admitted a link between the disease, known as bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), and a human equivalent, Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD).

Although the European Commission controversially eased in June 1996 a ban on gelatine made from British beef, it has not approved any such exports because British manufacturers failed to meet the strict heat processing pre-conditions.
British gelatine producers considered that the terms were so severe that they made production uneconomic. Instead they turned to beef raw materials from other countries.
Officials stressed that the draft gelatine ban was only part of a series of measures to tighten up BSE controls.
Fischler gave member states until the end of April to show that they were properly enforcing new EU rules on meat and bonemeal processing.
Recent EU inspections have shown that member states have not been respecting rules on the disposal of cattle and sheep offal. A number of member states could be taken to court.
Fischler is expected to make a fresh bid to ban specified risk material from cattle and sheep -- brains, eyes, spinal cord and spleen -- from human and animal food.

EU farm ministers rejected the proposal in December arguing that the measures was unnecessary and economically excessive given that their countries were virtually free of BSE and scrapie, a similar brain-wasting disease in sheep.
Infected meat and bonemeal mixed into cattle and sheep feed is believed to be the main cause of BSE.
